byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Nicole Perlroth from San Francisco.
byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

abstract: Study released by cybersecurity firm Norse shows that Iran has greatly increased skill and frequency of its cyberattacks, despite international sanctions and even while negotiating over its nuclear program; Iran has been named as entity behind devastating 2014 cyberattack on Sands casino in Las Vegas; some warn that lifting of sanctions under nuclear deal will allow Iran to further accelerate attacks.
lead_paragraph: A new study concludes that Iran has greatly increased the frequency and skill of its cyberattacks, even while negotiating with world powers over its nuclear program.

headline.main: Iran Is Raising Sophistication and Frequency of Cyberattacks, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Iran Is Raising Sophistication and Frequency of Cyberattacks, Study Says

snippet: A new study concludes that Iran has greatly increased the frequency and skill of its cyberattacks, even while negotiating with world powers over its nuclear program.

keywords.value: American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research
keywords.name: organizations
